_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
ConAgra International Fertilizer
Nickerson, KS.

I.    The Facility Policy:

The Facility owner, management, and employees of ConAgra International Fertilizer, are 
committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local 
responders are encouraged to visit the Facility to gain first hand knowledge of the site. 
Employees are required to hold monthly safety meeting and include sections of the 
Risk management in those meetings.  The Facility maintains an internal emergency                                                            contingency plan. If an accidental release should occur,the facility is prepared to work                                                           with local responders, and other authorities to mitigate any release, and to minimize the
impact of a release on the population and environment.

II.   Facility Information:

The primary activity of the Facility is to distribute agricultural fertilizer for the farming 
industry in the area.  Part of the fertilizer comes in the form of Anhydrous Ammonia, 
here after referred to as ammonia.  Ammonia is received, store, and used in the 
production of non-hazardous liquid fertilizer solutions. Ammonia is an important 
source of Nitrogen for agricultural crops during the spring and fall of the year.
 
The maximum quantity that can be stored at the facility is 131,300 pounds.  The typical 
method of receiving ammonia is by truck transport containing 40,000 pounds. Transports 
are unloaded through a permanent piping system constructed and maintained in 
accordance with industry guidelines and ANSI K61.1. The pipe reactor batch process is a large consumer 
of the product but is intermittently operated.  

III.  Accidental Release Prevention:
   
The Facility takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards           
Institute "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" 
K61.1, and Compr

essed Gas Association CGA G-2 for design, construction, and 
maintenance of the process equipment.  The Facility tries to minimize the amount of 
ammonia held or stored at the facility through management judgment. All employees 
involved with the handling and processing are trained and continue to update their 
training to be competent in the performance of their duties. The Facility continues to 
review and look for means to improve operating and best management practices for 
increase safety.  A Process Safety Management plan is also incorporated into the 
management of this system.


IV. The Five Year Accident History:
       
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia related to the operation of this facility 
in  the past five years.  There have been no deaths, injuries, or significant property 
damage at the Facility. To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, 
evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage has occurred 
due to the operation of this facility.







Bibliography / References:
Technical Inc. prepared for NIOSH, HAZOP of  "Anhydrous Ammonia Use in 
Agricultural" 1991.

Clements Associates, Inc., Fairfax, VA;  "Health Effects for Ammonia, prepared for The 
Fertilizer Institute.

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  "Chemical Emergency Preparedness and 
Prevention Advisory ? Ammonia", September 1991 Oswer 91-008.2, Series 8; No.2.

Ecology and Environment, Inc.,  "Generic Hazard Assessment and Off-site 
Consequences Analysis Kern and Kings Counties"' prepared for California Fertilizer 
Assoc. October 1990

American National Standard Institute, Inc., "American National Standard Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"  (K-61.1) March 
1989
